message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deepfakes and Disinformation: Exploring the Impact of Synthetic Political Video on Deception, Uncertainty, and Trust in News
Paper Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) now enables the mass creation of what have become known as “deepfakes”: synthetic videos that closely resemble real videos. Integrating theories about the power of visual communication and the role played by uncertainty in undermining trust in public discourse, we explain the likely contribution of deepfakes to online disinformation. Administering novel experimental treatments to a large representative sample of the United Kingdom population allowed us to compare people’s evaluations of deepfakes. We find that people are more likely to feel uncertain than to be misled by deepfakes, but this resulting uncertainty, in turn, reduces trust in news on social media. We conclude that deepfakes may contribute toward generalized indeterminacy and cynicism, further intensifying recent challenges to online civic culture in democratic societies.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Trust" and found multiple results covering different meanings of the term:

## Legal Definition
A trust is a legal relationship in which the owner of property, or any transferable right, gives it to another to manage and use solely for the benefit of a designated person.(no content)In English common law, the party who entrusts the property is known as the "settlor," the party to whom it is entrusted is known as the "trustee," the party for whose benefit the property is entrusted is known as the "beneficiary," and the entrusted property is known as the "corpus" or "trust property."

## Social Science Definition
Trust is the belief that another person will do what is expected, and it brings with it a willingness for one party (the trustor) to become vulnerable to another party (the trustee), on the presumption that the trustee will act in ways that benefit the trustor.

## Cultural Context
A low-trust society is defined as one in which interpersonal trust is relatively low and shared ethical values are lacking, while a high-trust society is one where interpersonal trust is relatively high and where ethical values are strongly shared.

The search also returned results for various works titled "Trust," including a 2022 novel by Hernan Diaz, a 2010 film, and a TV series that premiered in 2018, along with other uses of the term in business and music.

Here are the search results for "Social media":

## What is Social Media?

Social media are new media technologies that facilitate the creation, sharing and aggregation of content (such as ideas, interests, and other forms of expression) amongst virtual communities and networks.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Uses and Functions

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.(no content)They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Additionally, social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.

## Current Adoption

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Key Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Links: [{"title":"Disinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation"},{"title":"Disinformation (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation_(company)"},{"title":"Disinformation (TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation_(TV_series)"},{"title":"Disinformation (book) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation_(book)"},{"title":"Disinformation Governance Board - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation_Governance_Board"},{"title":"Global Disinformation Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Disinformation_Index"},{"title":"Counter disinformation unit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counter_disinformation_unit"},{"title":"Countering Foreign Propaganda and Disinformation Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countering_Foreign_Propaganda_and_Disinformation_Act"},{"title":"ChinaAngVirus disinformation campaign - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChinaAngVirus_disinformation_campaign"},{"title":"Soviet disinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_disinformation"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about disinformation:

## Definition

Disinformation is false or misleading information deliberately spread to deceive people, or to secure economic or political gain and which may cause public harm.(no content)Disinformation is an orchestrated adversarial activity in which actors employ strategic deceptions and media manipulation tactics to advance political, military, or commercial goals.

## Key Distinctions

In contrast, misinformation refers to inaccuracies that stem from inadvertent error.(no content)Scholars collectively agree that disinformation is the strategic dissemination of false information with the intention to cause public harm, while misinformation represents the unintentional spread of false information, and malinformation is factual information disseminated with the intention to cause harm.

## How It Spreads

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've completed a web search for "Artificial Intelligence" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## Historical Background

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Types of AI

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks. In contrast, weak AI (or narrow AI) can solve one specific problem but lacks general cognitive abilities.

## Applications

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data. AI has been applied across numerous domains including healthcare, astronomy, military operations, video games, and artistic creation.

## Current Progress

According to Stanford University's 2024 AI index, AI has reached human-level performance on many benchmarks for reading comprehension and visual reasoning.

Web search results for query: "Uncertainty"

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_principle"},{"title":"Measurement uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measurement_uncertainty"},{"title":"Knightian uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knightian_uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty management theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_management_theory"},{"title":"Propagation of uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propagation_of_uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_avoidance"},{"title":"Fear, uncertainty, and doubt - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear,_uncertainty,_and_doubt"},{"title":"Uncertainty coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_coefficient"}]

I've completed a web search for "Uncertainty." Here's a comprehensive overview of the key concepts:

## General Definition

Uncertainty or incertitude refers to situations involving imperfect or unknown information.(no content)It applies to predictions of future events, to physical measurements that are already made, or to the unknown, and is particularly relevant for decision-making.

## Different Types and Domains

**Economics and Risk:** In economics, in 1921 Frank Knight distinguished uncertainty from risk with uncertainty being lack of knowledge which is immeasurable and impossible to calculate.(no content)Knightian uncertainty is a lack of any quantifiable knowledge about some possible occurrence, as opposed to the presence of quantifiable risk.

**Physics:** The uncertainty principle states that there is a limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties, such as position and momentum, can be simultaneously known. In other words, the more accurately one property is measured, the less accurately the other property can be known.

**Measurement:** No measurement is exact. When a quantity is measured, the outcome depends on the measuring system, the measurement procedure, the skill of the operator, the environment, and other effects.

## Uncertainty Management

Uncertainty can be utilized strategically for beneficial purposes while also acknowledging that the effects of uncertainty can be harmful, espousing an approach that requires examination of each situation, the parties involved, the issues at stake and the desired objectives for determining the best method for managing uncertainty.

The search results reveal that uncertainty is a multifaceted concept studied across mathematics, physics, economics, psychology, and other fields, each with its own frameworks for understanding and addressing it.

Links: [{"title":"Audio deepfake - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audio_deepfake"},{"title":"Deepfake - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deepfake"},{"title":"Deepfake pornography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deepfake_pornography"},{"title":"Category:Deepfakes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Deepfakes"},{"title":"TAKE IT DOWN Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TAKE_IT_DOWN_Act"},{"title":"AI-generated content in American politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-generated_content_in_American_politics"},{"title":"Charmaine Poh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charmaine_Poh"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_politics"},{"title":"Algorithmic party platforms in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_party_platforms_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Generative AI pornography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_porn"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about deepfakes:

## Definition

Deepfakes are images, videos, or audio that have been edited or generated using artificial intelligence, AI-based tools or audio-video editing software.(no content)They may depict real or fictional people and are considered a form of synthetic media.(no content)The term "deepfake" was coined in 2017 on a Reddit forum where users shared altered pornographic videos created using machine learning algorithms.

## Technology

Deepfakes uniquely leverage machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques, including facial recognition algorithms and artificial neural networks such as variational autoencoders (VAEs) and generative adversarial networks (GANs).

## Concerns and Risks

Academics have raised concerns about the potential for deepfakes to promote disinformation and hate speech, as well as interfere with elections.(no content)Artificial intelligence is increasingly impacting elections globally, with growing concerns that powerful generative AI systems and deepfakes will destabilize democracies. These technologies make it easy for anyone with a smartphone and a imagination to create fake, yet convincing, content aimed at fooling voters.

A significant concern involves misuse: A 2023 analysis found that 98% of deepfake videos online are pornographic, with 99% of the victims being women.

## Recent Legislative Action

The Tools to Address Known Exploitation by Immobilizing Technological Deepfakes on Websites and Networks Act, or TAKE IT DOWN Act, is a United States law aimed for dealing with non-consensual intimate imagery or deepfakes posted to online sites and social media applications. The bill was signed into law by President Donald Trump on May 19, 2025.

Web search results for query: "Visual communication"

Links: [{"title":"Visual communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_communication"},{"title":"Journal of Visual Communication and Image Representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Visual_Communication_and_Image_Representation"},{"title":"Visual Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communications"},{"title":"Visual Communication (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communication_(journal)"},{"title":"Visual Communication Quarterly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communication_Quarterly"},{"title":"Graphic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphic_communication"},{"title":"Communication design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_design"},{"title":"Paul Martin Lester - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Martin_Lester"},{"title":"Visible light communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visible_light_communication"},{"title":"Graduation Day (upcoming film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graduation_Day_(upcoming_film)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about visual communication:

## Definition and Scope

Visual communication relies on a collection of activities, communicating ideas, attitudes, and values via visual resources, i.e. text, graphics, or video.(no content)Visual communication has become one of the most important approaches using which people communicate and share information.

## Key Components

The seven components of visual communication are: color, shape, tones, texture, figure-ground, balance, and hierarchy.(no content)Within modern culture, there are several types of characteristics when it comes to visual elements, they consist of objects, models, graphs, diagrams, maps, and photographs.

## Common Applications

Advertisements, teaching and learning, and speeches and presentations all involve visual aids that communicate a message, with the most common being: chalkboard or whiteboard, poster board, handouts, video excerpts, projection equipment, and computer-assisted presentations.

## Historical Importance

Many of the visual elements are forms of visual communication that humans have been using since prehistoric times.(no content)Though written or verbal languages are taught, sight does not have to be learned and therefore people of sight may lack awareness of visual communication and its influence in their everyday life.

## Evaluation Standards

The evaluation of a good visual communication design is mainly based on measuring comprehension by the audience, not on personal aesthetic and/or artistic preference as there are no universally agreed-upon principles of aesthetics.

Web search results for query: "Experiment psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_psychology"},{"title":"Category:Psychology experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Psychology_experiments"},{"title":"Stanford prison experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_prison_experiment"},{"title":"Milgram experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milgram_experiment"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Learning,_Memory,_and_Cognition"},{"title":"Society for Experimental Psychology and Cognitive Science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Experimental_Psychology_and_Cognitive_Science"},{"title":"Stimulus (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stimulus_(psychology)"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Human_Perception_and_Performance"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: General - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_General"},{"title":"Category:Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Experimental_psychology"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of experimental psychology:

## What is Experimental Psychology?

Experimental psychology is the work done by those who apply experimental methods to psychological study and the underlying processes.(no content)It's a branch of psychology that focuses on experimental design and the study of psychology in research settings.

## Research Topics

Experimental psychologists employ human participants and animal subjects to study a great many topics, including sensation, perception, memory, cognition, learning, motivation, emotion; developmental processes, social psychology, and the neural substrates of all of these.

## Historical Development

Experimental psychology emerged as a modern academic discipline in the 19th century when Wilhelm Wundt introduced a mathematical and experimental approach to the field, founding the first psychology laboratory in Leipzig, Germany.(no content)Charles S. Peirce randomly assigned volunteers to a blinded, repeated-measures design to evaluate their ability to discriminate weights, and this experiment inspired other researchers in psychology and education, which developed a research tradition of randomized experiments in laboratories in the 1800s.

## Famous Psychological Experiments

Some well-known examples of psychological experiments include the Stanford prison experiment, a controversial psychological experiment performed in August 1971 at Stanford University, designed to be a two-week simulation of a prison environment that examined the effects of situational variables on participants' reactions and behaviors, and the Milgram experiments conducted by Yale University psychologist Stanley Milgram, who intended to measure the willingness of study participants to obey an authority figure who instructed them to perform acts conflicting with their personal conscience, where participants were led to believe that they were assisting a fictitious experiment in which they had to administer electric shocks to a "learner".

Links: [{"title":"Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_psychology"},{"title":"Category:Psychology experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Psychology_experiments"},{"title":"Stanford prison experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_prison_experiment"},{"title":"Milgram experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milgram_experiment"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Learning,_Memory,_and_Cognition"},{"title":"Society for Experimental Psychology and Cognitive Science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Experimental_Psychology_and_Cognitive_Science"},{"title":"Stimulus (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stimulus_(psychology)"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_Human_Perception_and_Performance"},{"title":"Journal of Experimental Psychology: General - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Experimental_Psychology:_General"},{"title":"Category:Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Experimental_psychology"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of experimental psychology:

## What is Experimental Psychology?

Experimental psychology is the work done by those who apply experimental methods to psychological study and the underlying processes.(no content)It's a branch of psychology that focuses on experimental design and the study of psychology in research settings.

## Research Topics

Experimental psychologists employ human participants and animal subjects to study a great many topics, including sensation, perception, memory, cognition, learning, motivation, emotion; developmental processes, social psychology, and the neural substrates of all of these.

## Historical Development

Experimental psychology emerged as a modern academic discipline in the 19th century when Wilhelm Wundt introduced a mathematical and experimental approach to the field, founding the first psychology laboratory in Leipzig, Germany.(no content)Charles S. Peirce randomly assigned volunteers to a blinded, repeated-measures design to evaluate their ability to discriminate weights, and this experiment inspired other researchers in psychology and education, which developed a research tradition of randomized experiments in laboratories in the 1800s.

## Famous Psychological Experiments

Some well-known examples of psychological experiments include the Stanford prison experiment, a controversial psychological experiment performed in August 1971 at Stanford University, designed to be a two-week simulation of a prison environment that examined the effects of situational variables on participants' reactions and behaviors, and the Milgram experiments conducted by Yale University psychologist Stanley Milgram, who intended to measure the willingness of study participants to obey an authority figure who instructed them to perform acts conflicting with their personal conscience, where participants were led to believe that they were assisting a fictitious experiment in which they had to administer electric shocks to a "learner".


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Summary

I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Deepfakes and Disinformation: Exploring the Impact of Synthetic Political Video on Deception, Uncertainty, and Trust in News". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel experimental methodology and findings about deepfake effects)

**Triples Extracted:** 8 key entities identified with their relationships:

1. **Deepfake** (concept) - uses: The primary subject being studied
2. **Disinformation** (concept) - proposes: The paper explores how deepfakes contribute to it
3. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - uses: Foundational technology enabling deepfakes
4. **Trust (social science)** (concept) - proposes: Key outcome variable in the study
5. **Social media** (tool) - uses: Platform where deepfakes spread and trust is measured
6. **Visual communication** (concept) - uses: Theoretical framework for explaining effects
7. **Uncertainty** (concept) - proposes: Key mechanism identified for trust reduction
8. **Experimental psychology** (method) - uses: Methodology used for the novel experimental treatments

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully with 8 triples properly formatted and Wikipedia URLs verified.

Sources:
- [Deepfake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deepfake)
- [Disinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation)

- [Trust (social science)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(social_science))

- [Visual communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_communication)
